notes.description: Why color in DataViz matters - speed to insight
bulletPoints: Help viewers quickly digest information and remember it
Understand the meaning, impact, and most important details of the information presented
Used poorly can distract from the story, confusion
Do: create associations, show continuous data, show comparison/contrast, make important information stand out
Use common conventions, trigger associations and streamline understanding, eg orange for safety, country colors
Single color in gradients for amounts in continuous data
Don't: colors not easily distinguishable (7 or fewer), use too many colors
Qualitative - categorical variables; unrelated to one another
Sequential —  variety of saturations or gradient; ordered, numeric values, eg dollar amounts over time.
Diverging — spectrum, eg cold to hot; neutral color in the center and usually light to dark on either side

notes.description: User stories are development tasks often expressed as 'persona + need + purpose.'
bulletPoints: Template: 'As a [persona], I [want to], [so that].'
Why build this feature; end goals
Informal, general explanation of a feature; putting people first
Keep end users at the center of the conversation
Non-technical language providing context for the development team
Requirements and functionality are later discussed by team; technical and creative
Consider: Definition of 'done'; Outline subtasks or tasks; User personas; Ordered Steps; Listen to feedback; Time
As a [persona]: name, not just job title
'Wants to': describe intent, implementation free, no UI
'So that': desire to do something

445.resourceTitle: How to Choose Colors for Data Visualizations

notes.description: Color will highlight the story to be told
bulletPoints: Three major types of color palette: Qualitative; Sequential; Diverging
Qualitative: the variable is categorical. Categorical variables take on distinct labels without inherent ordering, like country, state, race, gender
Qualitative colors need to be distinct;  rule of thumb, limit to ten or fewer colors
Bundle smaller categories into 'other'
Adjust lightness and saturation for differences, but not too different as some colors will communicate greater importance
Sequential: variable is numeric or has ordered values; assigned in continuum, usually based on lightness and hue
Lower numbers are usually lighter, in light backgrounds. Use reverse for dark backgrounds, higher numbers lighter and brighter
Diverging: can span between 2 hues - warm to cool, with a meaningful central value like zero
Discrete vs continuous - clear blocks vs smooth gradient, former is clearer and used more
Avoid unnecessary color and be consistent across charts when same entity
Use color conventions like with sports teams or political parties
Use grey to reduce importance and create focus
Tools: Coblis Color blindness simulator; colorbrewer2.org; learnui.design color picker; Chroma.js; color-thief (inspiration from images); Viz Palette

444.resourceTitle: How Recursion Works — Explained with Flowcharts and a Video

notes.description: In order to understand recursion, one must first understand recursion.
bulletPoints: A recursive function is one that calls itself; recursion is where a function calls itself
Recursive approach can be clearer to read than loop sytax
No performance benefit to using recursion, iterative loops can be faster.
A lot of algorithms use recursion
Beware of infinite loops; function keeps calling itself
Always two parts: the recursive case and the base case
The recursive case: function calls itself; base case: when the function stops calling itself
Recursive functions use 'the call stack.'

Geographical: choropleth, cartograms

5. Leading the participant; care in phrasing questions, keep general

notes.description: Four commonly used mappings - Empathy, Customer journey, Experience, Service blueprinting
bulletPoints: Three-step decision framework - Current (today) vs. future (to-be); Hypothesis vs. research; Low-fidelity vs. high-fidelity
Empathy maps help team members understand the user’s mindset.
A customer journey map is a visualization of the process that a person goes through in order to accomplish a goal tied to a specific business or product.
An experience map is a visualization of an entire end-to-end experience that a “generic” person goes through in order to accomplish a goal
Service blueprints are counterparts to customer journey maps, focused on the employees.

Rerendering the entire DOM tree might look wasteful and overkill at first sight, but in practice, it’s not quite as bad as it sounds

notes.descriptor: JavaScript 'bind' method
bulletPoints: Allows you to attach an object to a function and then reference the attached (binded) object using the 'this' keyword.
Allows you to make functions that'll work across many objects with ease.
Without 'bind' method, a function will be attached to the global 'window' object
Values of 'this' change dynamically depending on what object is binded to the function

76.resourceTitle: Kano Model — Ways to use it and NOT use it

notes.descriptor: Kano model is a theory of product development. What are the must-haves and what is already expected?
bulletPoints: Very good at prioritising features - guaging depth of pain points; baselining features over a product lifecycle, natural decay of delight over time
'The natural decay of delight' by Daniel Zacarias
Innovative ideas move from exciting to expected
Each feature: measure satisfaction and sentiment
Five categories: attractive, performance, indifferent, must-be, undesired
How to use: questionnaire with each feature listed separately; ideally have a prototype; no demo, use text description; have / don't have feature - how do you feel?
Test 15-20 features max to avoid overwhelming interviewees
Add third question? how important is this feature?
7 point Likert scale; analytical process; numbers don't say WHY
using scenarios is good but they must be validated beforehand

notes.descriptor: Phil Gilbert of IBM Design gives a presentation on Design Thinking
bulletPoints: Takled lack of bold outcomes and speed of value creation across IBM middleware products
Deliver experiences that users love. A sustained culture of user-centric agility.
Framework - change 3 things: People, Practices, Places = sustainable outcomes
Gap analysis - where we are compared to where we need to be
Markets change too fast, have to have collaborative environment with different skill sets and decision making.
The client experience is where the value is at
Teams were STEM - Design was the lever to pull for greater outcomes
Change to STE-A-M with a ratio of 1:8
Be very intentional on diversity in teams
Add 1,500 Designers - small part of IBM
Design Thinking is a bedrock set of principles: 1 focus on user outcomes / 2 restless re-invention for continuous delivery / 3 diverse empowered teams
Observe-Reflect-Make loop
Observing is about immersing yourself in users's world (eg Red Cross disaster relief)
A sponsor user is someone actually using the product and is embedded in the teams giving a full day of time each week.
Sponsor Users are the easiest way to vet an idea, and cheapest way to fail.
2-Pizza team idea is wrong, better to have all branches of company user-centric, everyone has to be involved.
Reflecting is about converging on a point of view - Playbacks
Everyone sketches, we prototype relentlessly, stickys and sharpies
Ideas are easy - alignment is hard.
'Hills' are the high-level goals that everyone works towards in a 3 to 6 month timeframe
Cupcake / birthday cake / wedding cake - different levels of fidelity, before getting feedback
Design studio built in existing campus - no 'other' by having a cool space for designers only

27.resourceTitle: Putting Personas to Work in UX Design: What They Are and Why They’re Important

notes.descriptor: Jobs-to-be-done focus on user problems and needs, while well-executed personas include the same information and also add behavioral and attitudinal details.
bulletPoints: Definition: Jobs-to-be-done (JTBD) is a framework based on the idea that whenever users “hire” a product, they do it for a specific “job”. The set of “jobs” for the product amounts to a comprehensive list of user needs.
The purpose of personas are primarily as demographic representations of users.
Jobs-to-Be-Done: A Useful Tool to Focus on Outcomes Rather than Features.
Identifying for which goals customers “hire” your product.
JTBD is much less prescriptive than 'task analysis' and 'use cases' - the 'how'.
JTBD questions if typical activities to get outcomes are the most efficient.
Defined in sentence format, noting what users have to do, and any key contextual information.
JTBD doesn't promote empathy like personas, but both work together
Personas: needs, goals, expectations, behaviours, attitudes

Engaging, Readable, Skimmable - start with a hook line.
Use formats: bullets, italics, quotes, embeds, images, bold text, colour
Vary lengths of sentences, merge 1 sentence paras
Lots of white space - no hypnotising.
Triangulation and funnel formats.
Active instead of passive voice; drop filler '-ly' words; trim fat and edit
